storyInfo: Culann drags the sculpture to the city square and tries to make the masses see reason, but dies surrounded by the crowd's madness. Then, purple flames burn, and Eblana descends... The first fragmented story ends here, while the curtains slowly unfurl on the second.

attributes.content: Hundreds, thousands of years ago, the Tarans' ancestors did the same as their descendants do now, lighting bonfire after bonfire in the barrens between autumn and winter.
They would sleep beside the red dragon, their red-hot dreams buffeted by sand and wind until raw, but even so it was enough to keep everyone warm.
They would wake up to a still-burning bonfire, because the red dragon does not sleep.
With a moment's rest, the red dragon could find respite from fatigue and pain by breathing in the dreams of homeland, liquor, and freedom rising slowly from the flames and into the sky.
Today, Samhain approaches. The people fuel the flames with wood torn from nearby ruins, and have entirely forgotten the ancient leisure time that seemed to last forever.
Put your hand in the fire.
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Look at the color of the flames on my hip. I'm a Taran, I tell you, one blessed by the Red Dragon.
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: You think a spy couldn't fake the color of a lamp? Get on with it!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: May...
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: May the Red Dragon be merciful!
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: Oh... it... doesn't even hurt too bad.
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: Really?
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Look. You can barely make out the burn marks on my hand.
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: So you're not a Victorian spy. But do you know of anyone else who hasn't undergone the trial yet?
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: You. Yes, you! Have you burned your hand over there yet?
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: Say something, will you? Enough fiddling with that broken knot of yours! Come with me!
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: I'll take you there! Just put down the knot—
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: You—You hit me?!
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: My knot... you dared...
attributes.name: Quiet Resident

attributes.content: Fine, keep your bloody knot. Just come with me to see if you're not a Victorian spy!
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: The quiet resident stands up without a word, and heads towards the bonfire with shaky steps.
The square has already descended into complete chaos.
Though half of it stems from suspicion and hatred—not to mention frustration at having revealed no spies yet—the other half comes from the looks of despair and the deathly silence.
Until a faint sound of something dragged across the ground rumbles in the distance.
The sound grows louder and louder, until it drowns out all the clamor and chaos.
Everyone hears the sound of something massive slowly being dragged closer to them.
In a flash, every other sound fades, leaving only the shaking of steel and gears in its wake.
Hidden in the humid mist is the gigantic silhouette of an ice-cold statue.

Forged by a hero, and still considered incomplete by the townsfolk, the statue of the red dragon's ancestor is presented to Tara. It arrives in the raging light of the dying sun, yet even so nearly manages to shroud the sky.
The dragon statue... came to life?
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: No, that's—Culann?!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Culann, are you here to help us find the Victorians too?
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: He has to prove he isn't one first!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Over here, Culann! Listen, the fire won't hurt you as long as you're no Victorian—
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: Are you deaf?! Get over here already!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Hold on, he...
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: He dragged this giant statue all on his own?!
attributes.name: Anxious Resident

attributes.content: They finally notice the iron chains wrapped around his arms, one, two, three times around, and that the statue's weight was resting on those wide yet mortal shoulders.
The hero does not respond to his name and continues forward. The statue grinds down on him till it draws blood. His flesh is nearly rent asunder, his bones cry out in sorrow, and yet he presses on.

The young hero walks ahead of the statue, unafraid of the disparity between his small stature and the gigantic structure. He takes one step, then another, each heavy and certain, towards an open space in the crowd.
He parks the statue in the square's empty center, and struggles to turn around before facing everyone before him.
The steel skeleton bears an icy elegance, wings frozen in motion craving for flight, in place as if it were meant to be there since the beginning.
Stop, my brothers and sisters.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Before we kill any more of our own.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: For a moment, no one dares to respond.
Hate and doubt both remain, as well as the pain that keeps everyone from advancing towards him like an army of walking corpses.
The man before them is a hero. He protected Na Saoirsí. He dragged both blessing and curse all the way here, and the statue behind him laces his every word with an awe-inspiring weight.
Kill our own? Who?
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: You are burning hands with fire now, but what if your spy isn't found?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: He really dragged the statue here...
attributes.name: Nemos

attributes.content: What should we do? Should we... interrupt him?
attributes.name: Nemos

attributes.content: Did our food not return to us? Is the war not over?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Say there really was a spy. Why must the entire city gather here? Why must we hurt each other, just to find one lowly spy?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Let him... finish.
attributes.name: Loughshinny

attributes.content: I'll say it again. The war is over.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: When it had just ended, my thoughts were simple. I'd wait for a smith better than myself to arrive, then learn a thing or two from them so I could repair what I had made myself.
attributes.name: Culann
Culann
attributes.content: But...

attributes.name: Culann
attributes.content: No smiths came, and I learned no skills. I even took what you lot needed to live, and forged it into the statue.
That was wrong of me. Na Saoirsí is short of everything. Even an empty bowl is better put to catching rainwater than being cast into a shiny statue that does nothing but grow.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: And the food. I was so worried yesterday. So afraid that famine would put us past the point of no return. Maybe it was the Red Dragon's mercy, or maybe one of the ag plates had a good harvest, but the fact is, our food is back.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: And as long as we're alive, we can make it through this. Am I wrong?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: But Theo... is no longer alive.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: You still feeling pity for that Victorian bastard?!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Yes. I am. When I heard of his death, I began to hate everyone in this city, myself included.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: You know better than any of us what the Victorians have done!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: I know that with the last of their strength, they leaned over and begged me to take him away.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: I hate you all. I even feel like taking revenge on any of you who sat back and watched him die.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: But revenge needs a reason, doesn't it? What's our revenge for, then?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: To rob them just like they robbed us back then!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: And how do you suppose Na Saoirsí could manage to take even a single grain from the Victorians, when we've already melted our axes into this statue?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: We have to let those bastards feel the pain we went through.
attributes.name: Quiet Resident

attributes.content: Yeah, just like how I want to make you lot feel what it's like to die alone in an alley!
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Our brothers, our sisters died so we could live. Why must we now throw our lives away just to make others suffer?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Do you want us to love them, then?! To love those who stole our crops, killed our kin?
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: No, of course not. No one needs to love their enemy.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: All I want is for you to love the living... to love yourselves.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: But I don't even need you to do that, I just have one question for you all.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Tomorrow, once Samhain is over. Once the shadow of war finally leaves us... what will you do?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: I wanted to finish this statue and carve my name on it. But now? I want to find a better smith to teach me to fix up a prosthetic leg.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: I don't know what's up with the fancy speech all of a sudden, Culann. But I don't care what happens tomorrow, or about the war. I just want the Victorians dead.
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: So if you're speaking for them, I want you dead too.
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Fine.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Culann swings the sledgehammer he used to forge the statue towards the dragon's head.
However, he exhausts himself both in making and moving it, so with a moment's hesitation, the hammer does not come crashing down.
The crowd even assumes it to be some sort of ritual, and for a moment does not react to his plan.
Only when they realize Culann intends to destroy the statue do even the most dreary of the living dead collectively howl and dash in his direction, surrounding him.
Don't be foolish, Culann!
attributes.name: Nemos

attributes.content: Nemos's cry is drowned out by the crowd's yells, but Culann's voice remains clear for all to hear.

Loughshinny thinks of rushing over to him, but the angry crowd blocks her path. She bites her lip and tries to open a path through the sea of people with both her flames and voice, shouting to attract their attention.
Unfortunately, they act as if they have already lost their senses.
Maybe they truly have. Who can say?
I'm going to destroy this statue, in order to return the lives it took from you.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Destroy it?! How dare you!
attributes.name: Furious Crowd

attributes.content: I remember what each and every bone was forged from. I'll turn its spine back into axeheads and blades, its ribs back into bowls, its skull into tables and chairs. And give them all back to you.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Traitor! How could a hero like you betray us like this?!
attributes.name: Furious Crowd

attributes.content: If being unwilling to take someone else's livelihood makes me a traitor, then I was never a hero, but a traitor all along.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Excuses!
attributes.name: Furious Crowd

attributes.content: Excuses?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: I'll tell you who Culann really is. He is no hero. He is a liar who hungered for fame.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: He claimed to have killed a squad of Victorian scouts in the Dark Woods. But it was not in the woods that he met those Victorians, but somewhere further away...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: They weren't even scouts. Just a band of poor traders, already trampled over by some army or other.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: He wanted to save them, but in the end, could only save one boy. A Victorian child. He didn't know what to do.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Be it out of desperation or vanity, he decided to cut their heads off, and tell his people they were scouts.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: That way he'd become a hero, the most prestigious person in town. He thought he could use that status for good.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Raising the boy would become an act of mercy by the benevolent hero.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: You lied to us?!
attributes.name: Furious Crowd

attributes.content: Even this poor liar knew that he was still a blacksmith, and thought he should learn his trade after the war.
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: But you lot...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: What about you?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: You—You're not Culann! You're a fake, pretending to be him!
attributes.name: Friendly Resident

attributes.content: *cough*...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Yeah, you're not Culann! He's our hero, the man of steel who even a whole Victorian squad couldn't handle! Who the bloody hell are you?!
attributes.name: Fervent Resident

attributes.content: Hah...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: After dragging the statue all the way here from my workshop...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: How much longer... do you expect me to live?
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Fresh blood gushes from Culann's mouth and nose as if he has just uttered his last words.
He bears an almost kind and expectant gaze as he looks at his compatriots surrounding him. Hoping their faces will reveal an expression other than hate.
But he feels as if his eyes meet only a sea of purple flames. The faces behind the fire are difficult to discern, as if they are the restless dead he met in those ruins outside long, long ago.
He looks into the distance.
*cough* *cough*!
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: In a corner at the edge of the square he sees a tiny figure.
He did not have time to look for Theo's corpse, but now it stares at him blankly, purple flames clearly visible around it.
Theo? You too?!
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: *cough*...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: This was... all for naught...
attributes.name: Culann

attributes.content: Culann stumbles to his feet, and picks up his hammer to swing.
The crowd stares at him with dread, fearing that the hammer will fall on their heads, but they do not back down.
Culann uses the last of his strength...
And with the utmost ferocity, he strikes the dragon's head.
As if sounding a death knell.
The hero's body collapses before the giant dragon, stunning the crowd as if they've lost something.
Loughshinny's voice finally spreads as her fire burns like a sunset set aflame, but she fails to attract any attention.
At that very moment, the statue suddenly bursts into purple flames along with Culann lying quietly before it, sending the crowd reflexively into retreat.
Within the fire, Culann begins to pick himself up, while the giant statue extends its wings as if to fly away.
When Culann gets fully to his feet, the dragon statue flaps its huge wings, lifts off, and lands on the empty pedestal in the center of the square prepared just for it—
The crowd watches in complete silence, though whether out of shock or reverence is unclear.
From the citadel come the faintly discernible sounds of footsteps, slow and late.
Truly a shame that I missed the only hero left in this city.
attributes.name: Eblana

attributes.content: Well then, people of Na Saoirsí. Your hero has sacrificed his life for this statue.
attributes.name: Eblana

attributes.content: Nightfall approaches, so if you still follow the Red Dragon's will...
attributes.name: Eblana

attributes.content: Then you will obey curfew and head home.
attributes.name: Eblana

attributes.content: 'Culann uses the last of his strength, and with the utmost ferocity he strikes the dragon's head, as if sounding a death knell.'
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: You're quite the fan of Culann, I see. A tragic ending, but your embellishments made it beautiful.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: You flatter me.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: I only ever met the blacksmith a few times. He was the first victim of the city's chaos, if you don't count Theo.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Actually, I'm rather curious about something. The Dublinners who walked into the darkness, did they also bear the 'purple flames' you mentioned?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: I'm sorry, but I couldn't say.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Based on your story so far, I do not believe they would have. Corruption, smuggling, abuse of authority... They had many plans for the future.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: If you've thought about it that much, you could probably come up with your own ending by now.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: But that was not the only incident to occur in the city. You said so yourself: he was but the first victim.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Though, if you insist on ending this here...
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.text: The red dragon was certain those infected by the flames of death could not be saved.
And so, she declared to her people that the land would become death's domain, and they would become her followers, accompanying her on a journey towards death.

The corpse-like masses no longer had the strength to either consent or refuse. That night, flames rose high into the sky, illuminating the fields, and since then, no one has ever seen the red dragon or her followers again.

attributes.content: Ugh...
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: What is it?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Nothing. You can go now.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: There is obviously something.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: 'Since then, no one's ever seen the red dragon'? Really?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: The author glances towards the tavern wall, covered in newspapers no one has touched. Today's paper is there too, with a photo of The Leader gracing the headlines. It declares she is currently in Oak Grove for some ceremony or other.
Also, 'accompanying her on a journey towards death'... When did that happen?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Stories are free to go where they please.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Free, sure. But that doesn't mean we get to twist the tale beyond recognition and laugh it off.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Whyever not?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Because you and I, we're Tarans. Our stories will reflect us, no matter how distorted they become.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Oh? You still regard yourself as a Taran?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: I've been a Taran since the very first time I read a line penned by Seamus Williams.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Why else would I have abandoned the warm armchairs of Castshire County's literature salon and run all the way to Tara and become a—
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: 'You still regard yourself as a Taran?'
An extremely ominous thought flashes through the writer's mind, but he immediately rejects it.
He looks at the newspapers again. The papers report only facts, even if they are edited.
I'll just go ahead and ask. Who sent you?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: I'm here under no one's orders. As you put it, I'm simply an interested reader who wishes to help you 'piece together the truth.'
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Can you prove it?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: Now there's a conundrum. It'd be simple enough to prove someone did send me, but the opposite? How do I prove someone's nonexistence?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: The author takes another gulp of beer, despondently gripping his head. He knows it is too late to run.
But he can still turn things around. He just has to be clever about it...
I mulled it over, and you're right, it's just a story. I suppose I was a tad nervous. Apologies.
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: You do have quite a few unfinished tales as well.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: Perhaps we can join them together, and find an ending true to both Na Saoirsí as it was, and the Tara in your heart.
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: So if you're ready, then for the next story, how about we talk about the dance in the mirror?
attributes.name: Mysterious Woman

attributes.content: The... dance in the mirror? What?
attributes.name: Writer

attributes.content: No, this was not a matter of cleverness.
As long as he is prudent and lets the shadow of the story cast by firelight rise and warp, he will definitely be fine.
